div1.p: Carter writes about the French Debt Commission and states that she disagrees with some of Ravenel's article on her father but she appreciates the spirit in which it was written.

div1.head: Letter from Laura Armistead Carter to George E. Vincent, November 29, 1925
div1.opener:
[unclear]
Vincent
2121 California St., N. W.,
Washington, D. C.,
November 29. 1925.
Dear Doctor Vincent:
div1.p: As an addendum to my letter of this morning:

1: For some quite inexplicable reason, everyone I have tactfully in-
terrogated seems extremely non-committal about the French Debt Commission.
Indeed, the most “garrulous” statement I have so far been able to evoke
was that “if Mellon had been handling the business by himself things would
probably have been pleasanter.”

It is positively affirmed that the Commission was “properly met” by
J. Butler Wright, of the State Department, on whom this duty always de-
volves in the case of visiting celebrities--some of my informants stating
that he went to New York f for the purpose, others that he met the Commis-
sion here at Union Station. Of course, the historic incident of Smoot
putting his feet on the table towards the end of the conference is too
well known to repeat. Why there should be so much reticence on the sub-
ject I cannot imagine, would no effect on head should seem endangered
by the discussion. Still, that is Washington all over--things which would
seem to warrent the Bastille broadcast from the house-tops: appothers, appar-
ently quite harmless--taboo! If I ever hear anything of interest on the
subject I shall not forget to let you know of it.

2: In regard to Dr. Ravenel's reaction to the data I showed you, you
will find on Page 994 of the November Number of The American Journal of
Public Health that he is ill adheres to his theory in re Nott and Carlos Fin-
lay, but adds that “the observation of Dr. Carter probably had much to do
with Reed's return to that line line of study-- (of the mosquito transference)
vector). Dr. Ravenel's article on Father is sincere and generous and, while
I do not agree with him as to the part played by Father's work on extrinsic
incubation, I much appreciate the spirit in which it is written.

Also, it is not a matter for controversy. The work of the Reed overyd
and that leading up to it and determining its direction (in which must be
included that of Ronald Ross) was done, and well done by allc concerned and

With best remembrances to you and your household, including Mrs.
